title: In 'How to win friends and influence people', Dale Carnegie says 'Don't criticize, condemn, or complain'. What about when somebody has truly done something wrong? - Quora
tags: How to Win Friends and Influence People (1936 book)

response.answer_text: Dale Carnegie started his book by telling us bits and pieces about the two most notorious criminals (Murderer)— Two gun Crowley and Al Capone. They did terribly wrong and yet Criticism nor condemnation didn’t work against them. Instead, they’re saying that it was them who were wronged. So basically, if criticism, condemnation, nor complain doesn’t work on those who truly deserve condemnation, how much more will this affect us? I think the main point here is that every time you 3C other people, they’ll end up hating a bit of you 99% of the time. Well, They MIGHT change their behavior but you’re less likable to them. So I think it’s okay if you 3C on wrong behaviors as long as you don’t do it every time or else they’ll actually end up hating you.

I haven’t read the book, but I’d like to offer some insight. One of my primary rules that I try to live my life by is to always concentrate on the situation and not on the individual. Behaviors can be altered, and in doing so, we are helping people to have a better chance at success. It’s not an easy concept to remember, and in applying it, we have to remember to always forgive but never forget. I have run across some folks over the years who just weren’t a good fit for the teams that I was a part of. I’ve tried to help folks develop their skills so that they fit in better, but there comes a time when a person realizes that it is for the good of the team as well as that individual to cut ties. It’s not an easy decision to make, but it is the mentality that I use. If I can’t help someone be successful as part of the team, then I’m going to help that person be successful somewhere else.
